Game.title: Game
Game.description: Represents a game available in the GameSphere store.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Game entity.

description.description: A detailed description of the game.

releaseDate.description: The date when the game was released.

genre.description: The genre of the game (e.g., Action, RPG, Strategy).

developerId.description: The ID of the developer user who submitted the game.

imageUrl.description: URL of the game's main image.

status.description: The submission status of the game.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the GameSphere store.

id.description: Unique identifier for the User entity.

email.description: The email address of the user.

registrationDate.description: The date when the user registered.

Review.title: Review
Review.description: Represents a user review for a game.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Review entity.

rating.description: The rating given by the user (e.g., 1 to 5 stars).

comment.description: The text comment provided by the user.

reviewDate.description: The date when the review was submitted.

ShoppingCart.title: ShoppingCart
ShoppingCart.description: Represents the shopping cart for a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ShoppingCart entity.

createdDate.description: The date when the shopping cart was created.

Wishlist.title: Wishlist
Wishlist.description: Represents a user's wishlist of games.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Wishlist entity.

DeveloperApplication.title: DeveloperApplication

userId.description: The ID of the user applying.

developerName.description: The name of the developer or studio.

portfolio.description: A URL to the developer's portfolio.

reason.description: The reason for wanting to become a developer.

submittedAt.description: The date when the application was submitted.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to support GameSphere's core features, focusing on scalability, security, and ease of maintenance. Authorization independence is achieved by avoiding hierarchical `get()` calls in security rules. The structure leverages path-based ownership and membership maps for collaborative data, while segregating data based on access needs.  

**Authorization Independence:** For user-owned data such as shopping carts, wishlists, library, and developer applications, path-based ownership (`/users/{userId}/...`) is employed, eliminating the need to fetch parent data for authorization. Reviews include the `userId` and `gameId`, enabling direct rule application without parent document access.

**Structural Segregation:** Games are stored in a single `/games` collection since they have a uniform security posture (accessible to all users for browsing). User-specific data, such as shopping carts, wishlists, library, and now developer applications are stored under `/users/{userId}` to ensure private access. Reviews, while associated with both games and users, are stored at the root level but contain the `userId` and `gameId` to facilitate independent security rules.

**Access Modeling:** User-owned data follows the `/users/{userId}/{collection}/{documentId}` pattern. The reviews collection requires the `userId` and `gameId` to be present, to allow rules to validate that the authenticated user owns the review, and to allow listing reviews for a specific game (rules are not filters).

**QAPs Support:** Secure `list` operations are ensured through structural segregation. Listing games is open to all, listing shopping carts, wishlists and library items are restricted to the owning user via path-based rules. Developer applications can now be securely listed by the user who owns them.

**Role-Based Access Control:** The `User` entity now has a `role` field. The `Game` entity has `status` and `developerId` fields. Firestore rules will use these fields to enforce that only `dev` users can create games, and only `admin` users can change a game's `status` or a user's `role`.
